To a reader without context, it might seem a bit odd that I would not recommend a well known title like Valve's original "Portal". Widely regarded as a breakout title for the developer and a close second behind their landmark "Half-Life" series, "Portal" made a number of Game of the Year lists and was a welcome addition to the famous Orange Box. The story and concept of this title are well-known and I will not dwell on them too deeply here, but suffice it to say that "Portal" was a big cultural moment in gaming once, and was the must-have title in any platform or puzzle collection. This Steam title is only slightly changed from the original release (I'll explain a little later) so a player should have the same experience with "Portal" as they would have had in 2007, right?

Well, no. I'm not offering my opinion in 2007, but rather many years later and a lot has changed. Today, the title is terribly aged and creaky, very short and the story was more enjoyable when it was original. Back in 2007, the original "Portal" had a novel concept, interesting puzzles, dark humor and enjoyed a pop culture moment. In part [b]Because Of[/b] the unexpected success of the original, today we enjoy a universe of platformers and puzzle titles including Valve's much-improved sequel "Portal 2" which doesn't seem to have aged a day since 2011. There is a certain amount of credit owed to the 2007 original for opening a 'portal' into what platformers could be in the future, but we have to judge it today by its own merits and enjoyment.

Sticking with just the original 19 levels for a moment, they are moderately challenging and most players will not need help eventually solving them, although they may need a minute or so to think about the physics of most rooms. Hazards become more regular as Chell continues through the testing center but the game is forgiving of errors and deposits you near the last safe platform most times. The challenge level is enjoyable and, if that's all that matters to you, then the game may still be worth playing through.

The story is enjoyable in a folksy sort of way - a mad testing robot and a facility where the staff lost control. It's been done before in other places but was intriguing back when it was original. There's plenty of dark humor in the game with faux sympathy from a synthetic intelligence. The choices it forces from the protagonist and the methods by which the core protects itself is meant to be about 70% amusing and 30% threatening which is just the right balance. The game also doesn't ramp up the difficulty near the end to try to increase total game length, and that's welcome. My character actually died a few times in the last few test chambers but not a single time following the escape. But if you've ever played through the game before, then the jokes really aren't as crisp as when they were fresh and all the warnings are already understood. We know that "The Cake is a Lie"

The graphics are normal for 2005-ish and not really inspiring. Starting from the first testing chamber, you've already seen 60% of all the surface area in the game, it just gets copy-pasted for the rest of the facility. The later levels where you see the lattice and girders behind the testing chambers is pretty amusing, as though the developers are saying they know the scientific panels are just duplicated and this was an intentional design choice by Aperture Science to keep the facility looking as uniform as possible throughout. Eventually you navigate into gritty industrial areas] as part of the late game, but these areas are also 2 dimensional texture surfaces and are also not impressive.

The soundtrack provides only minimal ambiance and doesn't really signify rising or falling action until late in the game. This works okay and it isn't central to either the plot or the gameplay. Your only audible companion in the facility is the peculiar computer and it's unknown plans for you, and this provides some comic relief to break up the monotony of testing. It's not so much that the soundscape is either insufficient or misplaced, but for a game where the speed often feels sluggish, the script is often what barely holds your interest. It's a little amusing, and in those long elevator rides between levels it's all you've got.

The game is not long, and I consider that a positive attribute. The average player will probably complete "Portal" in two hours or possibly less. I did not personally experience any stopping points during the original 19 stages or the last chapter that forced me out of the game to YouTube for an answer, and I don't think most players will need help, but there's no shame if you do. The very last stage with GLaDOS is a little unintuitive, but not a terrible boss fight and is as good an ending as might be expected. The closing scenes are the most memorable and a terrific artistic production.

One of my single greatest complaints about this particular release of "Portal" are the Challenges and Advanced Maps released in this updated edition of the game. These were supposed to add new life and vitality to the game by upping the difficulty and that is exactly what they do - straight up to Masochism. The new levels are simple recycling of earlier testing levels, but floors and other surfaces on the original route can no longer receive portals and now you must use other paths at nearly impossible angles. In several of these maps, you are required to (1) shoot new portals while flying at full speed in the opposite direction or (2) dodge indestructible turrets across open hallways or (3) bounce dangerous currents of energy in uncontrollable directions to strike a precise conduit in a closed room. While the Advanced Maps are 'solvable' mostly, they are not 'enjoyable' and require a lot of both trial-and-error and mortal failure. All of them feel especially lazy and seem to almost require exploits or game-breaking features to progress. I was able to solve the first 5 Advanced Maps eventually by myself and broke after several minutes on the 6th and just looked up a solution. I don't want to offer an opinion of the game just based on the new maps, but they're easily the worst feature of the latest edition and should not have been included in any official release. Maybe a mod, but not the official version.

Steam requires that recommendations be either 'Yes' or 'No', but I feel like this one should be 'Meh'. It's not that "Portal" is bad, but it's just that everything is better than "Portal" now, like "Portal 2" for example. There is a cultural moment for everything and we have all lived through fads such as Flappy Bird, Fidget Spinners, Yu-Gi-Oh, Angry Birds, Gangnam Style, and Pokemon GO. The original "Portal" was a product of its time and an interesting cultural landmark. You may find it amusing to play through today if you already own the title, if only for the nostalgia value.

But should you go out and buy it on Steam?

Pribeh zacina v malej bunke (kde je ppc radio keby mozem berem zo sebou) a postupne ste vyzivany k plneni uloh aby ste sa dostali dalej. Ako dalej postupujete odhalujete pribeh ktori bol za mna velmi dobry. Kedze nemam rad dlhe recenzie hru zhrniem.

Plusy: 
+perfektna fyzika ktora sa tak casto nevidi
+super pribeh 
+napatie co sa bude diat a vynikajuca atmosfera (najma ku koncu hry)
+na svoju dobu dobra grafika ktora dokaze obstat aj po cca 20 rokoch 
+bonusove challenge a levely

minusy:
-otvoreny koniec 
-hru som presiel za 3 hodiny (bez bonusov)
-nemozes si brat radio zo sebou
-malo achievementov 




Overall hra je super a tesim sa na stiahnutie 2ky. Urcite kupujte v Portal Packu/Bundle.

Portal: 

-Present√≥ mec√°nicas muy interesantes para su momento.

-Su narrativa juega con la inocencia del espectador que almenos a m√≠ parecer es un gran atino que posteriormente ver√≠amos m√°s desarrollado y mejor planteado en la segunda entrega.

-Considero que este juego fue la piedra angular para lo que hoy conocemos como el "Universo Valve"por presentar easter egg que lo vinculaban con la saga Half-Life.

-Los niveles, a pesar de ser habitaciones con puzzles no se sienten para nada repetitivas y mucho menos tediosas, est√°s influyen mucho en el contexto narrativo.

-Se experiment√≥ mucho con el motor Source trayendo nuevas novedades a este √∫ltimo, por lo que podr√≠amos considerar que fue un juego prototipo para explorar m√°s a fondo las mec√°nicas de este motor.

En fin, el juego es asombroso!. Considero que todo fan√°tico de Valve deber√≠a de tener est√° joya en su biblioteca.

Portal is an easy game to learn with simple rules and controls. It is difficult, but you choose how to play and you decide how challenging it can be. The moment I walked through my first portal, I already knew this is gonna be one of the best games I will ever play. The graphics, the levels, the story, and the characters make this game so immersive that I feel like I am really holding a portal gun trying to pass the "test". I finished the main story, but there are bonus maps and challenges to complete, not to mention how I can  play this game over and over again and still be amazed by the mechanics and the story. The song at the end credits is an icing to the cake. Ahhhh. Now I am scared at the mention cake.

This is, in my opinion, one of the greatest games of all time. Top 5 at least, The gameplay is fun and creative, the story is interesting and the humourdarkand amazing and super funny. Plus, it's on sale very often.

I have not finished the game yet but I have enjoyed it so much already! I love the puzzle style and mechanics. I got stuck in a corner during the Turret level because i put too many things in my way and i was trying to get out, giggling the whole time, for twenty minutes.
Sometimes if you miss something obvious or at least feel like you did it can be frustrating realizing you were stuck on such a simple puzzle for so long, but solving them is one of the most satisfying feelings I've had playing a game in a long time!
Extremely ahead for its time and has aged like fine wine, incredible game.

"Hello and, again, welcome to the Aperture Science computer-aided enrichment center."

Portal, ese tipo de juegos que hacen volar la mente. Simplemente una obra maestra; una inmersi√≥n total. Misterioso y lleno de retos que pondr√°n a prueba en todo momento tus habilidades analiticas. Un juego bastante corto, pero que lo compensan los puzzles que pueden llegar a ser un poco d√≠ficiles. Adem√°s, el ambiente de misterio, los distintos escenarios, y la m√∫sica son puntos a favor que hacen de este juego algo maravilloso.

La historia del juego es inescrutable, cuentas con muy poca informaci√≥n para saber el trasfondo de GLaDOS y de las instalaciones de Aperture Science. Sin embargo, el c√≥mic "Portal 2: Lab Rat" es esa herramienta que ayuda a entender los sucesos de Portal. Ahi se aprecia un poco del trasfonodo de GLaDOS y por que Chell est√° ahi. Portal 2: Lab Rat cierra la brecha que hay entre Portal y Portal 2, un c√≥mic que ayuda a solventar varias incognitas. Leer Portal 2: Lab Rat es esencial para el juego ya que se aprecia la historia de Portal desde una perspectiva diferente, adem√°s es relativamente corto. Portal, a trav√©s de los ojos de Doug Rattmann.

8/10

Ho sempre amato Portal.
La storyline √® molto semplice, minimal, esattamente come il design e la direzione artistica in generale. Ma √® proprio questo (e non solo) che fa di Portal un gioco davvero interessante da scoprire e da giocare.
I puzzle sono davvero ben strutturati, tanto da invogliarti a risolverli e a riprovare successivamente ai fallimenti,
Il gioco ha parecchi anni ormai, ma la grafica e la gestione dell'illuminazione rimangono sempre un punto forte. In sostanza, non √® per niente invecchiato male.
sono contento di averlo acquistato e (ri)giocato dopo tanti anni, la sensazione che mi ha restituito √® soltanto migliorata.

A very fun game that cleverly turns what looks like a first person shooter into a puzzle game.  I found the humor throughout very entertaining and with a relatively short playing time is a piece of gaming history everyone should try out.  You even get a piece of delicious cake!
Good game in general. I also got my science teacher to let us play this instead of studying advanced physics.
